instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message:
This board came in completely dead, no green light or anything. Made a visual inspection of the board, and oddly enough there where no sign og water damage at all.
The <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> had a small crater on it so it got replaced. After replacing the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> I got green light and the fan started. Mounted the board back in the machine and found the machine running quite slow and not recognizing the battery. Tried with a well known battery, but still nothing. The BIL doesn't show anything when pressing the button either (tried two different ones as well).
The board does run on a charged battery but does not show up in OS. Ran ASD with noe errors.

Started measuring around the board:
- Current sensing resistors <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>-52 seems fine
- <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> Pin 5 is only 5-7V when battery is not connected
- <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> both measures good, and is receiving 3,42V
- The J6955 looks great

While sitting here writing I just realized that I haven't checked <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> or <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> yet. I will do this ASAP.

I do fear a bad SMC, but if anyone has any suggestion to other things I should check I would appreciate if you shared with me :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message: If another battery doesn't fix it then it is a bad SMC. Also disconnect the battery indicator first.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message:
Thank you, I have already tried with other batteries and without the battery indicator. I have never replaced SMC and do not have equipment for it. I do however have some boards with SMCs on them.
I guess I will need to re flash the BIOS as well if I just replace the SMC? Do I need to re-ball the SMC or is it possible to do this only by adding solder to the pads?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message:
Only need to change SMC nothing more. Reball SMC with 0.3mm balls and use direct heat stencil.
[url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/tools/2387-smc-stencil-and-reballing-base[/url]

Or order programmed SMC:
[url]https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/New-For-MACBOOK-PRO-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-SMC-EC-CHIP-i5-i7-CPU-P-N-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B/32736893716.html[/url]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message:
Excellent, I think I'll order both, it's about time I learn to replace SMCs anyway :).
Thank you.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message: Removed the SMC now, and there are several pads missing, I guess this is a "no fix" board :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message:
Uhm you killed it!.....Why did you not practice on scrap board??
Check in board view if the missing pads are not connected.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message:
I removed one from another board first :), no missing pads there. I may have killed it, but what did I do to kill it?
I'll check the pads

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message: All missing pads starts with NC_ does that mean "Not Connected"

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message: Yes those are not connected. Practice on scrap board with the dead SMC first. This board is perfectly fixable and it would be a shame to kill it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not seeing battery
threads.message: Replaced the SMC and the board seems completely fine now, you can mark this as solved
